docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Leslie Gordon believes that studying her son's rare and fatal disease may shed light on the process of normal aging. But at its core, the scientific pursuit is really about saving a boy.

headline.sub: Dr. Leslie Gordon believes that studying her son's rare and fatal disease may shed light on the process of normal aging. But at its core, the scientific pursuit is really about saving a boy.

docs.snippet: Dr. Leslie Gordon believes that studying her son's rare and fatal disease may shed light on the process of normal aging. But at its core, the scientific pursuit is really about saving a boy.

docs.lead_paragraph: AIDS among infants, which only a decade ago took the lives of hundreds of babies a year and left doctors in despair, may be on the verge of being eliminated in the United States, public health officials say. In 1990, as many as 2,000 babies were born infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS; now, that number has been reduced to a bit more than 200 a year, according to health officials. In New York City, the center of the epidemic, there were 321 newborns infected with H.I.V. in 1990, the year the virus peaked among newborns in the city. In 2003, five babies were born with the virus.

headline.main: U.S. Is Close to Eliminating AIDS in Infants, Officials Say

docs.abstract: American doctors may be on verge of eliminating AIDS in infants, when as recently as 1990, 2,000 babies were born with AIDS every year; success in fighting mother-to-child transmission is largely because of better drugs, but also aggressive public education and testing as well as cooperation at federal and local levels; tide turned when 1994 study showed that drug AZT reduced risk of transmission of HIV from mother to child by 67 percent; graph; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Mother-to-child transmission of H.I.V. has dropped so sharply that public health officials now talk about wiping it out.

docs.lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, the British pharmaceutical company GlaxoSmithKline introduced a vaccine against rotavirus, one of the world's leading child-killers. The debut of Rotarix is particularly newsworthy because it took place in Mexico -- this is the first time a major drug company has bypassed America and Europe to introduce a vaccine. Glaxo plans to extend Rotarix to other Latin American countries and Asia by the end of the year. It has applied for approval in Europe and will eventually do so in the United States. An earlier vaccine against rotavirus, made by Wyeth, was pulled from the American market in 1999 for safety reasons. Because of this, some people will no doubt argue that by postponing approval in the United States, Glaxo is attempting to dump a possibly unsafe product in the third world. The opposite is true; by rushing to offer the product in a poorer country, Glaxo is speeding the vaccine directly to where it is most needed. It's a long-overdue step that makes perfect sense.
docs.snippet: For the first time, an important vaccine is bypassing Europe and America and going directly to where it is needed most.
